intro: Styphelia megacarpa, commonly known as the giant waxflower, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Mexico. It is a member of the Ericaceae family, which includes heaths and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen shrub form. The plant features small, urn-shaped flowers that are typically pink or white, and it produces large, leathery berries that contain the seeds. Styphelia megacarpa thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and is often found in coastal or mountainous regions. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological and horticultural study.
